title: 1  Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.1.1 Search Engine

Search “Python for VS Code”
Go to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/python
Click “Python Tutorial”
Click “Install Python for python.org”



2.1.2 Python.org

Click “Download Python 3.XX.X”
Open the installer from Downloads
Check both boxes when the “Setup” prompt comes up.
After the install, select “Disable path length limit”



2.1.3 Test Python

Windows Key
Type “terminal”
In terminal, type “python”
In Python, type:


print("hello world")

hello world

title: 1  Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.2 Install VS Code

2.2.1 Aside

It is of great benefit to us as learners that VS Code includes “Copilot” (LLM) integration.



2.2.2 Install

Go to https://code.visualstudio.com/
Click “Download for Windows”
Open the installer from Downloads
Check all four boxes when the “Setup” prompt comes up.
After the install, select “Launch Visual Studio Code”



2.2.3 VS Code Setup

Use Copilot, or don’t.
Choose your theme
Select “Browse Language Extensions”

Select “Python”

Keep this window open

Select “Jupyter”
Optionally, look into R in Visual Studio Code

Click through the remaining options.



2.2.4 Python extension setup

Create a new Python project
Create a new folder, likely Documents/DATA505
Create a file “hello.py”:



hello.py

# hello.py

print("hello world")


Click the [>] button to run the file, which should print out to the terminal:

hello world

Return to the Python tutorial.

Click “CSelect Python Interpreter”
Select the version of Python you installed earlier.

title: 1  Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.3 Install Quarto

2.3.1 Search Engine

Search “Quarto”
Go to https://quarto.org/
Click “Get Started”
Click “Download Quarto CLI”



2.3.2 Install Quarto

Run the Installer

All default options are fine.

Install the VS Code Extension.

Go to https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=quarto.quarto
Click the “Install” button.
Allow the installation in VS Code and your browser.

Setup Python for Quarto

title: 1  Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.4 Install Jupyter
*To work with .qmd files, Python needs a package akin to R “languageserver”

Go to https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/hello/vscode.html
Run the following terminal command:

If you lost your terminal, create a new one from the menu.

py -m pip install jupyter matplotlib plotly

This will take a moment.

Following the Quarto tutorial, make hello.qmd
Click “Run Cell” in hello.qmd on this cell:


import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()







Figure 2.1: A line plot on a polar axis






When prompted, install the ipykernel
I restarted VS Code.

title: 1  Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.5 Cleanup

2.5.1 Quarto Preview

To test whether the process worked, open hello.qmd in VS Code.
Quarto preview hello.qmd either by pressing [>] or by using ctrl+shift+k.
After a moment, a document will be displayed, in VS Code and if you wish, in browser.



2.5.2 Render .md
To make this document.

Prefix the .md document with a .qmd header:

---
title: "Python, VS Code, Quarto"
format:
  html:
    code-fold: true
jupyter: python3
---

Rename from fname.md to fname.qmd

I did this by creating a new file and using copy+paste

Use quarto render fname.qmd either:

In the VS Code integrated terminal, or
At the command line, e.g. Windows Key+“terminal”

title: 2  Quarto Books and GitHub Pages
text:
3.1 Install Python

3.1.1 Search Engine

Search “Quarto Books”
Go to https://quarto.org/docs/books/



3.1.2 At the Terminal

Created a folder called “work”.
I ran the following in the terminal:



Terminal

quarto create project book mybook


I will be prompted for a title

I used “Python Stack”

I will be prompted if I want to open in vscode

I accepted.




3.1.3 In VS Code

Generating the book project automatically generated a _quarto.yml file.



_quarto.yml

project:
  type: book

book:
  title: "mybook"
  author: "Jane Doe"
  date: "8/18/2021"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - intro.qmd
    - summary.qmd
    - references.qmd

bibliography: references.bib

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
  pdf:
    documentclass: scrreprt
  epub:
    cover-image: cover.png


I updated the file to be as follows, with only two chapters:



_quarto.yml

project:
  type: book

book:
  title: "Python Stack"
  author: "Prof. Calvin"
  date: "1/9/2025"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - VSCode.qmd
    - Books.qmd

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
  pdf:
    documentclass: scrreprt



3.1.4 After Creating the Book

I view the initial book by opening a .qmd file and using Preview

By default on Windows, Crtl+Shift+K

I include some content in my new .qmd files.

For me, this was a prior lecture @chap1
